posts.name: Luiz Guilherme Forest Gomes
posts.cooked: We’ve had significant challenges due to the limited time allocated for programming the robot. This year, we barely had a week to set everything up properly. To address these issues last regional, we utilized the WPILib API to simulate our drivetrain effectively. Now, we aim to enhance our capabilities by incorporating simulations of other subsystems and achieving full 3D visualization, which we plan to implement using Advantage Scope. Despite spending considerable time reviewing the physics simulation and mechanism simulation docs from WPILib, we haven’t found much success (and I’m not particularly adept at interpreting technical documentation). Therefore, I’m reaching out for guidance on where to begin with mechanism simulation and any tips for effectively using Advantage Scope.
I am working on a few things to help solve this very problem and am looking for beta testers. If you're interested, please join the YAGSL Discord server and I can share the details there.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked: I strongly urge you to look into Nstrikes project here. It seems like it will benefit both you and your team.

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: When the user submits a request for a loan, the system automatically generates a proposal based on the information provided in the application form. The system also tracks the status of each loan application, allowing users to monitor their applications in real-time. Additionally, the system provides notifications when an approval or rejection decision has been made on a loan application. This functionality ensures that users are kept informed about the progress of their loan applications, and it helps maintain transparency within the financial institution.

posts.name: Otto
posts.cooked:
This past year was our first year performing extensive simulations, and we discovered several key insights:

1. 3D Simulations aren't particularly useful for real-world applications; while they're great for impressing judges or teams and offer an intriguing experience akin to reviewing machine replays (though they can be time-consuming to set up, ranging from 30 minutes to several hours).

2. Similar to 3D simulations, creating physics-based models for robots, including collision detection, tipping, etc., doesn't provide significant benefits beyond appearances before judges or teams.

3. Simulating your state machine or command logic drastically speeds up testing. We reduced our testing time for verifying whether a mechanism moves when a button is pressed from 30 minutes per subsystem to 30 minutes overall, enabling us to focus more on auto-aligned processes, which is the primary advantage of simulation.

4. AdvantageKit-style IO layers are highly beneficial. For example, you can access detailed documentation [here](https://docs.advantagekit.org/category/template-projects). Additionally, the best resources for learning about simulation are likely available in the AdvantageKIT WPILib documentation or other team members' repositories. If these options don't work for you, consider asking for help in the main Discord server.

When starting with a simple mechanism, it's recommended to use code from your past year's bot and incorporate IO layers. You can either adapt existing code or consult the relevant documentation. If that approach doesn't yield results, seek assistance from the main Discord community.

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked:
The text was cleaned up by correcting minor grammatical errors, ensuring clarity, and maintaining a professional tone while preserving the original meaning. Here is the revised paragraph:

"I would like to agree. 3D displays of mechanisms 2D are all you need. I will continue to set up mechanisms 3D because it is an easier way to check logic than using just bars, allowing game components to be visualized instead of just color-coded lights. However, something like Maplesim is often not worth the time during building season. Maybe it will be cool or useful in the offseason, but it will almost certainly not help improve robot performance on the field."

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: Maple Sim with Advantage Kit/Scope were clutch for us this summer

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: In AdvantageScope, you can show a 3d pose as a game piece without having to do the full robot CAD approach. A Mechanism2d plus an accurate-ish game piece pose is likely enough to visually validate behavior.

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: If you are visualizing game pieces, you are likely more experienced with doing mechanism 3ds as well.
